title: Evolutionary Reasons to Sleep
content: Sleep has become stigmatized as laziness and sloth. In 70 years, we’ve lost 20-25% sleep. By comparison, imagine a reduction in O2 saturation by 20-25%. Sleep is the foundation of health. In terms of de-risking just about every disease that is killing us in the developed world, it’s very hard to look no further than sleep. Nutrition and exercise are important, but sleep is the foundation. Deprivation of sleep causes the quickest reduction of health. Guinness has banned trying to set record for sleep deprivation because it’s so dangerous (cancer, mental health, CVD, metabolic syndrome, suicidality).

title: Stages of Sleep, Sleep Cycles, and Brainwaves
content: Humans (mammals) have 2 stages of sleep: Non-REM and REM sleep. Non-REM has 4 stages‒ cleverly titled stages 1, 2, 3, and 4. Stages 3 and 4 are the very deep restorative stages. Stages 1 and 2 are the lightest stages of sleep. Non-REM + REM sleep combine to form 90 minute sleep cycles. Every 90 minutes, your brain cycles between non-REM and REM sleep. Then this is replayed every 90 minutes to create what we call a standard cycling architecture of sleep, or what we call a hypnogram of sleep.

title: Understanding Sleep Chronotypes and How Knowing Yours Could Help You
content: Your sleep chronotype simply means are you a morning person, an evening person, or somewhere in between. Sleep science breaks it into 4 categories: Extreme morning types, Morning types, Middle evening types, Extreme evening types. There is a strong genetic component underlying sleep chronotypes. Evidence that it’s genetic‒ There is a significant degree of heritability. There are a collection of genes that will determine, to a degree, your chronotype. Data from 23andMe says there’s about 9 different genes that will contribute to your chronotype. Most are what we call “clock genes”‒ this refers to the fact that these genes control the rhythm of your circadian cycle.

title: Understanding Sleep Chronotype
content: Determining your sleep chronotype can be done through paid genetic tests like 23andMe or free online surveys like the MEQ test. Knowing your chronotype can explain why you might struggle with sleep where others do not, and can sometimes explain incorrectly diagnosed insomnia. When your chronotype is mismatched with your schedule, you may struggle to fall asleep.

title: Sleep Efficiency and Duration
content: Sleep duration refers to actual sleep, not just time in bed. Sleep efficiency is the time you are asleep divided by the time you are in bed. If you need 8 hours of actual sleep, and your sleep efficiency is about 90%, then you need to be lying in bed for approximately 8 hours and 50 minutes. This is referred to as sleep opportunity.

title: Correcting Insomnia: A Counterintuitive Approach
content: If you're struggling with insomnia and you're lying in bed awake a lot of the time, you may need to decrease your time in bed to increase sleep pressure. This can help re-establish confidence that you can fall asleep in bed.

title: Pros and Cons of Napping
content: Naps as short as 17 minutes can produce learning and memory benefits. However, napping can take away sleep pressure which could exacerbate nighttime sleep issues. If you're struggling with falling asleep at night, avoid naps during the day.

title: Sleep Hygiene and Wind-Down Routine
content: Sleep hygiene tips include regularity, getting lots of darkness at night and daylight during the first half of the day, keeping a cool temperature, not lying awake in bed, and avoiding caffeine in the afternoon and alcohol in the evening. A wind-down routine is also critical for good sleep.

title: Optimal Room Temperature and Body Temperature for Sleep
content: You need to get cool to get to sleep. The regulation of the sleep-wake rhythm is more tied to temperature.

title: Optimal Sleep Environment
content: In summer when it’s hotter, people sleep less at night but tend to take naps in summer afternoons to make up for that. In winter when it’s cooler, they sleep longer at night. The frequency of daytime naps decreases. The optimal room temperature for sleep is between 65-67 degrees. Warming up extremities (hands and feet) can help you fall asleep faster. Then you need to get cold to stay asleep during the night. And then you need to warm up to wake up in the morning. Other tips for cooling your core body temperature include taking a hot bath or a shower. To fall asleep faster, warm yourself up with a hot shower to radiate that heat out and get you to sleep quicker. Keep the room cool to keep your body cold throughout that middle section and later section of sleep. Then, set your thermostat to rise in the last 15 minutes of your sleep so you will wake up easier and feel less groggy.

title: Impact of Blue Light on Sleep
content: Blue light from devices like iPads can have a detrimental effect on sleep by delaying the release of melatonin, causing a reduction in REM sleep. However, it's suggested that these devices activate us, and that activation masks/mutes our sleepiness so we go to bed later and lose sleep. It’s less about the blue light, and more about the devices ability to increase alertness/physiological arousal in the brain.

title: Caffeine and Sleep
content: Caffeine can disrupt your sleep. The dose and the timing make the poison when it comes to caffeine. If you’re drinking it later in the day, you’re less likely to see those health benefits. In fact, you would likely see health detriments. Even when consumed in the morning, caffeine can affect the quality of deep sleep. There are genetic differences in how quickly people metabolize caffeine. Some people have very little sensitivity to caffeine, for example, and for those people caffeine in the morning is fine.

title: Dangers of Sleeping Pills and Alternatives
content: Sedative hypnotics like Ambien and Lunesta don’t actually get you into your good sleep stages. They seem to weaken the immune system leading to higher rates of infection and increased cancer risk. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is a nonpharmacological, psychological method working with a therapist that is just as efficacious as sleeping pills in the short term. The benefits can last for years after stopping therapy. Benadryl-induced sleep also has some of the risks associated with it that sleeping pills have. It’s less potent in terms of that bad consequence and outcome to sleep. There's not enough data yet to suggest that Tylenol PM is either good or bad.

title: Sleep Spindles
content: Sleep spindles are short synchronous bursts of electrical activity that happen during non-REM sleep. They last for 1-1.5 minutes. They are critical for things like learning, memory, and brain plasticity. Sleep spindles occur at the end of a deep, slow wave. Once you’ve hit the peak of that slow wave, you will often have a little bit of a spindle burst (that burst in tandem is called phase amplitude coupling). This coupling is critical for long term memory transfer and for strengthening connections between brain cells (brain plasticity or long-term potentiation).

title: Effects of GHB or Xyrem on Sleep Spindles
content: When you take GHB or Xyrem, the amount of sleep spindle activity is decreased. Blocking these sleep spindles can prevent typical memory and brain plasticity events. Therefore, Xyrem and GHB are not recommended to people who do not have narcolepsy.
